ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

WIDENING OF CANTONMENT ROAD
(Effect on Cantonment School and Keppel School)


    1. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education to what extent will the road widening project currently in progress at Cantonment Road affect Cantonment School and Keppel

Column: 970

School, and what plan his Ministry has to meet the situation.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Cantonment Road widening project has taken up some 0.37 hectares out of a total combined land area of 0.89 hectares of both Keppel School and Cantonment School. The project requires the demolition of: -

    (i) the school dental clinic at Keppel School; and

Column: 971



    (ii) the basketball court and part of the playing field of Cantonment School. The schools will be affected by dust during construction of the road and by noise from road traffic when the road is completed.

    The PWD will reinstate the affected facilities within the school compound other than the dental clinic at Keppel School. Children who need dental care will have to travel about 1 kilometre to the Institute of Health. Sufficient outdoor assembly areas will be provided for the schools. A 3-metre brick wall will be erected along the roadside outside the schools to reduce the noise. This wall will be decorated with creepers and other architectural finishes.

    In the long run, however, the schools will have to be resited as the present sites are located in an environment which is not very suitable for schools. Resiting of these two schools under the Ministry's School Building Programme is being planned. Suitable alternative sites not too far from the present sites, so that the new schools can serve the same pupil catchment area as the present schools, will have to be found first.

    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development when all the farmways in Lorong Buang Kok and Lorong Cheng Lim will be metalled.

LOANS UNDER SMALL INDUSTRIES FINANCE SCHEME


    4. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) how many local entrepreneurs have been granted loan classified as "establishment of new viable business" by the Economic Development Board under the Small Industries Finance Scheme up to the latest convenient date; and (b) in order to encourage more local professionals to become industrial entrepreneurs, whether the EDB will release a list of "viable industries" from time to time so that local engineers, technicians and industrial managers will be able to work out their plans for the establishment of industries under that Scheme.

     The Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 31st December 1978, 91 local companies were granted 110 loans amounting to $15.2 million under the Small Industries Finance Scheme (SIFS). Most of the loans were for expansion, upgrading of product and process and diversification of product lines. 14 loans were for the establishment of new enterprises or for the setting up of new product lines by existing companies.

    It is not possible to provide a list of "viable industries" to enable local engineers, technicians and industrial managers to identify projects for establishment under the scheme as every industry has its successful and unsuccessful projects. Apart from factors such as cost and market conditions, the success of a project depends on the ability of the entrepreneur.

    The Economic Development Board can provide some guidance to local industrialists

Column: 973

regarding the general condition in an industry. It can also suggest ideas of potential projects or provide introductions to joint venture partners. But, ultimately, it is up to the individual investor to find his own business opportunities. That, after all, is the hallmark of a successful entrepreneur.

    There are plenty of opportunities for local entrepreneurs. Many of the investment teams that EDB receives from abroad each month have shown interest in ordering components or even entire products from Singapore manufacturers. Those planning to establish plants in Singapore have frequently indicated their intention to enter into subcontracting relationship with local supporting industries. EDB will continue to introduce these foreign industrialists to local manufacturers.

    Head R -

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head R be reduced by $10 in respect of Object Group 1100 of Subhead Code RA-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in moving this amendment, I am merely taking the opportunity to raise an old issue with the Hon. Finance Minister concerning the non-

Column: 974

payment of the 13th month allowance or part thereof to civil servants when they retire, or to their dependants should they die pre-maturely. This issue was raised with the Finance Minister in this House during previous Budget debates without success.

    The Minister has always maintained that when the decision to pay the 13th month allowance to civil servants was made in 1972, it was explicit then that it did not cover instances of retirement or premature death. No one is disputing with him that that was, in fact, the decision. What is in dispute is that his decision was not fair and equitable, especially to long service civil servants who have served the Government faithfully, some for as long as 35 years. They are to be told on their retirement that they are not entitled to the payment of the 13th month allowance, while raw recruits into the civil service are immediately given the 13th month payment or part of it on a pro-rata basis in the first year of their service.

    It is not too late for the Minister to relent on this issue and modify the policy of payment of 13th month allowance to include civil servants who retire or die prematurely.

    Let me come to another matter that has also been raised in this House before. It concerns the plight of pensioners. Many pensioners, especially those who depend on their monthly pensions for survival and have no other sources of income, are finding great difficulty to make ends meet. With the cost of living escalating and the purchasing power of the dollar shrinking each year, will the Government not consider adjusting the monthly pensions upwards according to the annual NWC recommendations? I am raising these old issues despite past futile attempts, in the hope that with the passage of time the Hon. Finance Minister will mellow-down, relent, and be more sympathetic.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Employment Act an employee, when required by his employer to work on his rest day or any public holiday, is paid an extra day's salary at the ordinary rate

Column: 975

of pay for a day's work. This is in addition to the ordinary rate of pay for that day.

    However, this provision does not cover an employee of the Government or of a statutory body if such an employee comes within the definition of any of the essential services as laid down in Pan Ill of the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act, i.e. employees include those in the gas and electricity services, public health services, postal services, telephone and telecommunications services, and port services. Instead of an extra day's pay, such employees are given a day or part of a day off, as the case may be, in substitution for such work on a rest day, or holiday, or part thereof.

    Sir, quite often there is a shortage of manpower in many Government departments and statutory bodies. The granting of time-off in lieu of monetary compensation makes the situation more difficult. Some employees in the public sector are known to have accumulated so many hours of leave due to them that they have lost count of them. Needless to say, it becomes an administrative headache for their heads of department too.

    In one example, three employees of the Public Utilities Board are known to have accumulated over the last three years time off-in-lieu amounting to a total of more than 680 hours. Employees in the essential services, who have to work on their rest days or public holidays have to interrupt what they have probably planned to spend with their families on such days. Their planned leisure and other activities are disrupted. Although in theory he can have a day off later in substitution, it is more the rule than the exception that the substituted day of rest never comes.

    In fairness to employees in the essential services, the Government should set a stipulation of, say, two weeks during which any time-off owing to an employee should be

Column: 976

granted. If a department or statutory board is unable to grant time-off within two weeks, the hours worked should be converted to monetary payment. Otherwise many employees in the essential services will continue to work without rest days or monetary compensation.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, what I intend to raise under this vote has been partly answered earlier and a few days earlier. However, in view of the reply by the then Senior Minister of State for Finance, may I elaborate on the point regarding salary review in the civil service. I think the Government has emphasised over the last few months the need to retain brilliant scholars and top brains and to try to retain one-third of these in the civil service. I think it is time for the Government to review the salaries of this category of people, and also to consider a review of the salaries of the others in Divisions II and III in the civil service.

    The second point which I had raised two years previously is with regard to medical benefit for female civil servants. Sir, we know that in the Civil Service medical benefits are extended to the wife and the children of a male employee. However, the same does not apply to female employees in the civil service. I would say that today's society is such that more and more women are employed in the civil service and other sectors, and I am just wondering why the Government could not consider extending the same medical benefits to families of female employees. Many of them may have husbands who are not enjoying medical benefits of the civil service.
2.45 p.m.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong) rose -

     The Chairman: Mr Ho, are you going to speak on the same subhead?

     Mr Ho See Beng: Yes, Sir, I have an amendment for it. At the last meeting of

Column: 977

Parliament in January this year, I referred to a case where Singapore Airlines, a wholly-owned company of our Government, dismissed an employee on the ground that, at the time of applying for a job, he had concealed the fact that he was a former drug addict. SIA, Mr Speaker, Sir, had taken great pains to convince us that the employee had not been dismissed simply because he was a former drug addict, but because he had concealed the fact in his application for the job. SIA adopted the posture of a benevolent employer, but it would appear that they have erred.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, since I raised this matter in Parliament, a legal officer of the Government has stated that probationers, juvenile offenders and those sent to the drug rehabilitation centres for treatment need not disclose their previous offences when applying for a job in the civil service. I quote him:

    'Indeed, it will not be wrong for such people to claim that they have no conviction in the application for employment.'

In other words, they could specifically and confidently say "No Conviction" in answer to the question, "Have you ever been convicted in a court of law in any country?" A former drug addict need not answer this question when he applies for a job in the Government. And yet, Mr Speaker, Sir, we have a glaring case of a wholly-owned company of the Singapore Government dismissing an employee on the ground that he did not disclose the fact that he was a former drug addict. It is thus clear that Singapore Airlines was ultra vires when they took action to terminate the service of this unfortunate victim in our society who chose to exercise his constitutional right. May I therefore ask the Minister for Finance what action has been taken to chastise the officer responsible for this unwarranted action and what action has been taken to ensure that this does not happen again?

    Sir, I would also like to ask how many Government servants have been dismissed

Column: 978

for similar offences? In other words, in how many instances have the Government Ministries breached the law?

    The law is very specific in the matter of probationers, juvenile offenders and those sent to the drug rehabilitation centres for treatment. The law even requires the Registry of Criminal Records to deliver to a person who was acquitted, or discharged without conviction, his finger impressions, negatives and photos. And here, I would like again to quote the legal opinion expressed:

    'If no such application is made within three months from the date of acquittal or discharge, the Registrar must destroy the sheet containing the finger impressions and every negative and photograph.'

This is the measure of protection the law gives to people accused of such offences.

    Sir, I mentioned previously that the Government has set up institutions and drawn up rehabilitation programmes at great cost so that the unfortunate victims of drug addiction should have the facilities to kick off the habit and, when rehabilitated, should be provided with equal opportunities to lead normal lives and be given employment opportunities to enable them to regain their places in society.

    Sir, in order to achieve this objective the Government has enacted laws to ensure that victims of drug habits should not be marked down as criminals, to the extent of requiring that the records of those charged but acquitted without conviction are destroyed. These laws and regulations have to be implemented by the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Ministry of Social Affairs. And yet we have had this glaring case of a company under the Ministry of Finance blatantly ignoring the law and imposing its own rules and regulations.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our Government enacts laws which must be abided. It is a sorry state of affairs if one Ministry chooses to ignore the laws enacted by the Government on behalf of another Ministry. If this state of affairs goes on, our entire legal framework will collapse and the laws of the jungle will

Column: 979

prevail. This drift must therefore be halted immediately and the law must be upheld.

    Sir, this issue highlights the absence of a coordinating body representing the Ministries to ensure that Government's policies are implemented uniformly and equivocally by the different Ministries and authorities concerned. This body could also monitor the activities of different Ministries and statutory bodies and Government-owned companies under their purview so as to ensure that there is no contradiction in the implementation of policies.

    Sir, I mention this need at our session in January, and I would like to ask whether Government has taken cognisance of this need so as to ensure that Government's policies are interpreted in the way that Government intended them to be, and not be left to individual Ministries to provide their own interpretations which may well be in direct contradiction of the intentions of the Government, to the extent of even flouting the law.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the present state of affairs makes a mockery of the concept of the collective responsibility of Cabinet which is a corner-stone of the democratic parliamentary process.

    I would also like to ask the Minister for Finance this question. In view of the legal opinion expressed by the Government legal officer that applicants applying for jobs in the civil service need not disclose their past conviction, I wonder whether the Minister still insists on applicants applying for jobs in the civil service to answer the question, "Have you ever been convicted in a court of law in any country?" If the Minister for Finance says that the question is necessary and ought not to be removed, will he then consider introducing legislation to regularise the legal position.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to bring to the Hon. Minister's attention two matters which I would urge him to look into, namely, the poor salary scale of the customs officers and the issue of uniforms to Division IV officers,

Column: 980



    At the last budget session, I pointed out that from 1970 to 1977, although there were 1,020 new appointments in the customs service, yet at the same time, there were 508 resignations, or about 50% of the number of recruits. In some years, for example in 1976, the percentage of resignation was as high as 90%. Such a very high turnover of staff must certainly cause anxiety and concern to the Ministry, yet little seems to have been done to improve the situation.

    The major contributing factor to this alarming situation is the very poor salary scale of the customs officers. The consolidated salary of a new officer is $250 and he has to work for 19 years before he reaches the maximum of $600. But even before he reaches $600, he has to cross a number of obstacles, namely, the departmental examination and the confidential report of his superior. In fact, as a result of the present system. there are 45 officers who have not been able to cross the various salary bars and have stagnated. This is very unsatisfactory indeed.

    Sir, the customs officers have a very responsible job. This is because they are vested with statutory powers which enable them to act on behalf of the following departments: Import and Export Department, Foreign Exchange Department, Primary Production Department, Port Health Department, Chemistry Department, Marine Department, Postal Department, Registry of Home Affairs, Social Welfare Department, Trade Marks Division, Commercial Crimes, Controller of Supplies and Immigration Department. These are additional to their main responsibility of collection of revenue and implementation of preventive action.

    No wonder, Sir, there has been such a large turnover of staff. After a while, officers would not tolerate the shabby treatment they receive from the Government. The salary scale was drawn up in 1959, 20 years ago. Surely this is very outdated. On this matter, Sir, the then Senior Minister of State for Finance stated, when asked this question during the last budget debate, that he would look into the situation seriously, implying that

Column: 981

he would do something to improve the situation. I ask the Minister now, after studying the situation for a year, whether any measure has been introduced to improve the working conditions of the customs officers.

    The other matter relates to the issue of uniforms to the Division IV officers. There is an agreement between the AUPE and the Government under which the Government agreed to provide uniforms to all Division IV uniform grades on an annual basis. Unfortunately, Mr Speaker, Sir, some departments have not carried out their side of the bargain to the satisfaction of the officers concerned.
3.00 p.m.

    The main problem lies in the tender system for the supply of uniforms. As a result of the poor supervision to ensure that the requirements in the tender are carried out satisfactorily, the officers in a number of departments either have not received their uniforms or if they have, have found the uniforms most unsuitable for them. The common faults are listed as follows: excessive delays, poor fitting and poor sewing of the uniforms. In many cases, although the officers were measured individually, the completed uniforms were not found to be in conformity with the measurement. Officers in the Telecommunications Authority of Singapore, nurses in the Government hospitals and those in the Singapore Fire Brigade, have complained of these faults. Another complaint of the Singapore Fire Brigade officers is that they have not been given uniforms annually: they have only been allowed to replace their old uniforms. This is against the agreement that uniforms should be issued on an annual basis, and not on a replacement basis.

    I hope the Minister will look into these matters, particularly the tender system for the issue of uniforms. I would like to suggest to the Minister that a way out is either for the departments to issue the cloth to certain

Column: 982

designated tailors to which the officers can then go to have their uniforms made, or for the departments to give a uniform allowance to each officer.

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff (Kolam Ayer): Sir, the Straits Times of 6th March, 1979, reported that the then Senior Minister of State for Finance, Mr Goh Chok Tong, had said that the Government was considering a revision to improve the 1973 leave scheme. My question is, will the Government discuss the revision with the unions concerned? I raise this question because when the Civil Service Leave Scheme was revised in 1973 to allow civil servants to commute their vacation and medical leave into pay, the matter was discussed with the unions representing the public service.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Sir, there have been quite a lot of comments on quite a variety of matters. I would like to deal with them in accordance with the order in which they were made.

    First of all, the Member for Moulmein has raised his usual yearly question of the 13th month non-pensionable annual allowance. The arguments for and against paying civil servants who retire before the end of the year have been made so many times that, I think, the Member will not be very interested in hearing the arguments all over again. I can only repeat what I have said before, that this 13th month salary payment is only paid to officers in service at the end of the year. That is the main condition for the payment of this 13th month salary supplement, and if that condition is not fulfilled, then the payment is not made. I know that perhaps in drawing the line at "the 31st of December" we may have caused hardship or dissatisfaction to some civil servants, but in the nature of things if you have to draw a line the result must be that some fall on one side of the line and some on the other side. On this, I fear I will not be prepared to make any changes. Maybe if he raises this long enough, there will be another Minister for Finance to make the changes.

Column: 983



    I sympathise with the Member for his concern for pensioners, since I am one of the pensioners myself. I would very much like to have annual increments according to the NWC, as a pensioner, but as the Minister for Finance I am afraid I must draw a distinction between the National Wages Council recommendations which are for wages; that means, with serving employees and not with pensioners. So if he likes to take up the cause of pensioners, he should take it up in another connection and not in regard to NWC payments.

    I think the Member for Alexandra also raised the matter about the 13th month payment.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon: Point of clarification, Sir. I did not raise it.

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: If he did not raise the matter, then I do not have to answer him on that point. He raised the question of employees in the essential services of Government not being paid an extra day's salary for working on public holidays but that they were given a day off instead. This is really a matter for the administrators. There ought not to be people having entitlement, as he mentioned, of 680 hours. If the administration of that department was correctly done, then there ought to have been recruitment of additional staff or some other arrangement should have been made for these hours to be worked off. If, in fact, there are such cases, then the administration of that department should be looked into further. If he would give me information on the departments, ministries or statutory boards involved, then I will get my Management Services Department to look into the matter. The solution which he suggested could be one of the ways in which we can deal with this matter. But I would be reluctant to follow that particular course of action because in certain services of Government it is quite clear that overtime must be worked. It is part of the job, and people who enter into the public service on the conditions which are made known to them, should not expect to be given the

Column: 984

same benefits as the employees in the private sector.

    In regard to the Member for Kim Seng, he asked about salary review in the civil service. For Division I civil servants, I think the responsibility for review lies with the Prime Minister or with the Minister in charge of the Establishment Unit in the Prime Minister's Office. In the Budget debate some information has already been given about the salary review being undertaken. As for Division II and other services, I think that with the yearly increments that we are giving under the NWC there is no necessity in the same way to consider revisions of salaries. But from time to time we do consider changes which have resulted because of anomalies or unusual conditions, or if certain career development prospects are necessary in order to attract recruitment into particular services, then reviews will be made.

    He also raised the question of female civil servants being given medical benefits in the same way as the male civil servants so that husbands, for example, can benefit. I think I have answered this question quite in detail and I do not think I have any new argument to offer. I merely put it to him that as males, husbands ought to be enjoying better salaries and better benefits in positions of higher authority and emoluments, and there is no need for this concession to be given to female civil servants.

    The Member for Khe Bong made an excellent speech. He seemed to think that the constitution, the civil service and so on, will all be affected if his particular problem was not dealt with in the way that he considered satisfactory, I am not responsible for the Director of Legal Aid or his views. I believe he did say that a drug abuser need not disclose his previous conviction when applying for jobs. That depends on what the purpose of the job is. The argument was that the fact that a person was sent to a drug rehabilitation centre was not really a conviction and need not be disclosed. That is different from saying that he need not disclose his previous conviction. This is, of course, a legal point. If the magistrate binds

Column: 985

people over, so that a conviction is not recorded, or sends him to a drug rehabilitation centre, maybe without a conviction being recorded, then obviously that person is not a convict. I assume that under certain circumstances it may not be necessary to answer questions about conviction, if one has not been convicted.
3.15 p.m.

    But I think in certain sensitive departments it is very necessary to know the nature or the character of the applicant, whether he is subject to certain pressures in his job. For example, if he were a cashier in a bank or a pilot of an airplane, it may be necessary to know whether, in fact, he has a tendency towards drug taking and whether he has been convicted in a court of law. In those circumstances, I think it is pertinent that application forms should contain questions about such conviction, and I do not think there is any need for either the Government or the Singapore Airlines to apologise for asking questions which are necessary for particular jobs. In manual occupations, say, an operator in a factory putting transistors together, maybe there is no necessity to find out whether the applicant has any tendency to take drugs.

    The Member for Serangoon Gardens raised questions about the Customs and Immigration Services. In the case of the Immigration Department, there has been a request for a revision of salaries of officers and this is being examined by my Budget Division. But I would repeat my previous statement that in general the present Government policy is not to consider a salary revision except where necessary to rectify anomalies, to facilitate staff deployment or improve career development prospects.

    The Member spoke about the high turnover of staff in the Customs Department, I am not aware of this and maybe there has been no complaint because recruitment has filled most of the vacancies. So maybe it is not quite so serious a matter as the Member

Column: 986

thinks. In any case, if there are these high turnovers then obviously my Budget Division should look very carefully at the situation.

    The next matter he raised was on the uniforms for Division IV grades. I am not quite sure what we can do about the system that we now have for obtaining uniforms for Division IV staff. The usual practice now is, of course, contract tailoring.
